channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Some Covid rules to be eased early in Wales
item.description: Some lockdown restrictions in Wales will be eased earlier than planned due to falling Covid cases.

item.title: Covid: Deaths in England and Wales fall 92% since January peak
item.description: The drop in England and Wales comes amid efforts to reassure the public about vaccine safety.

item.title: Belfast: Police attacked during another night of violence
item.description: Petrol bombs and fireworks have been thrown at police near a peaceline in Northern Ireland.

item.title: Gillingham stabbing: Sir Richard Sutton named as victim
item.description: Police were called to a property in Dorset after Sir Richard Sutton and a woman were stabbed.

item.title: Greensill lobbying row: Rishi Sunak texts to David Cameron released
item.description: Labour calls for an inquiry into "lucrative contracts" awarded to an employer of the former PM.

item.title: Richard Okorogheye: Mother does not believe son took his own life
item.description: Richard Okorogheye's mother, Evidence Joel, says she does not believe her son took his own life.

item.title: Covid patient receives world's first living donor lung transplant
item.description: A woman in Japan becomes the world's first Covid patient to receive a transplant from living donors.

item.title: Phillip Adams: South Carolina shooting suspect named as former NFL player
item.description: The suspect killed himself after allegedly shooting five people in South Carolina home on Wednesday.

item.title: Manchester Arena bomber's brother calls prison guard 'filthy pig'
item.description: Hashem Abedi and two other men are accused of assaulting an officer in HMP Belmarsh last May.

item.title: UK sport bodies back use of 'vaccine passports' to allow return of capacity crowds
item.description: The UK's leading sports bodies are backing the use of 'vaccine passports' and Covid testing as a "credible" means of allowing full capacities at venues.

item.title: Ukraine conflict: Moscow could 'defend' Russia-backed rebels
item.description: A senior Kremlin official issues a warning as tensions rise in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Attacked man in coma 'after standing up for son'
item.description: Alan Willson went to the park after his son called him to say he was under attack.

item.title: HS2: Arrests as 'Roald Dahl wood' felling starts
item.description: Protesters and HS2 workers clash as work begins on felling a wood said to have inspired the author.

item.title: Ribblehead viaduct: Major restoration scheme completed
item.description: Engineers have worked on the £2.1m project at the Ribblehead viaduct throughout the winter months.

item.title: Deep sea mining to help make electric vehicles
item.description: Many companies want to exploit deep sea minerals but campaigners warn it could damage fragile ecosystems.

item.title: Newham art wall: 'Other than the murders, everything is fine'
item.description: A poem in a Newham mural praises a local library and parks, but calls the crime rate "unfortunate".

item.title: Why white US evangelicals are ‘hesitant' to get Covid jab
item.description: A survey finds religious affiliation influences coronavirus jab uptake, a psychologist explains why.

item.title: Holocaust Remembrance Day: Israel stops to remember victims
item.description: Traffic stopped and people stood in silence to honour the six million Jews killed by the Nazis during World War Two.

item.title: Gorillas may ‘communicate’ size through chest beating
item.description: A study of mountain gorillas in Rwanda suggests the animals use drumming sounds to share information about their bodies.

item.title: Wiltshire pub's new chalet 'breaks Covid rules'
item.description: The bar, with pizza oven and TV, does not comply with outdoor shelter guidelines, a council says.

item.title: London knife deaths: Mums tell of hardest calls after sons stabbed
item.description: Commissioner Dame Cressida Dick hopes the 'tragic accounts' will persuade people to call Crimestoppers.

item.title: Liverpool Banksy rat mural moved to Netherlands auction
item.description: The piece, which once adorned a former pub building, is being moved from the UK.

item.title: What is behind the violence in Northern Ireland?
item.description: Brexit, paramilitaries and the fallout from an IRA man's funeral lie behind rising loyalist tension.

item.title: Clubhouse: Is the audio app really worth $4bn?
item.description: A report suggests Twitter considered paying the sum for the rapidly growing live-audio app.

item.title: Are pay-by-the-minute booths the future of work?
item.description: A Singapore-based firm has come up with a useful alternative when working from home is inconvenient.

item.title: Women with disabilities 'groped and not taken seriously'
item.description: Women with disabilities are twice as likely to experience sexual assault as non-disabled, figures show.

item.title: I Can See Your Voice: The show where singers are judged on appearance
item.description: A new BBC One game show asks whether you can spot a good singer based on their appearance alone.

item.title: The woman who took on Google and won
item.description: When Shannon Wait was suspended after posting about working conditions, she fought back.

item.title: Local elections 2021: A simple guide to English council elections
item.description: Your introduction to the local council elections taking place on 6 May.

item.title: France and Covid: Call My Agent star joins plea to reopen theatres
item.description: Grégory Montel believes the French government must allow theatres and cinemas to start working again.

item.title: Indian Premier League: The risks of hosting the IPL during a pandemic
item.description: The world's richest cricket tournament will see eight teams play 52 games behind closed doors.

item.title: The tech billionaire who is putting women first
item.description: Whitney Wolfe Herd, the 31-year-old founder of dating app Bumble, has joined the billionaires' club.

item.title: Crate escape: Search for Irishmen who airmailed Brian Robson home
item.description: Were you in Australia in 1965? Did you help a homesick Welsh friend send himself home in a crate?

item.title: Where are Britain's loneliest places in lockdown?
item.description: Loneliness in the pandemic has been more intense for young people in poor, urban areas.

item.title: Slavia Prague stun Arsenal with stoppage-time equaliser
item.description: Slavia Prague score a dramatic stoppage time equaliser to leave Arsenal's Europa League ambitions hanging in the balance.

item.title: Granada 0-2 Manchester United: Marcus Rashford and Bruno Fernandes on target in first leg
item.description: Manchester United take a big step towards reaching the Europa League semi-finals with an away first-leg win over Granada.

item.title: Masters 2021: Matsuyama and Harman share lead as McIlroy and Westwood struggle
item.description: Hideki Matsuyama and Brian Harman share the early clubhouse lead at the Masters as Rory McIlroy and Lee Westwood struggle.

item.title: Who takes captaincy? And who plays in goal? Key questions for Lionesses before friendlies
item.description: As England prepare to take on France and Canada, there are questions still to be answered before the Team GB squad is announced.

item.title: The Masters 2021: Rory McIlroy hits his father on leg with errant shot
item.description: Northern Ireland's Rory McIlroy picks out his own father, Gerry, on the seventh hole, striking his leg with an errant approach shot on the way to a four-over par 76 in the opening round of the 2021 Masters.

item.title: Grand National 2021: Cloth Cap heads Aintree field as The Storyteller is withdrawn
item.description: The Storyteller is the only withdrawal as the final field of 40 horses is named for Saturday's Aintree Grand National.

item.title: Rare blood clots - what you need to know
item.description: We take a look at why these unusual clots happen and when they occur.

item.title: Covid: How does the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine work?
item.description: People under 30 are being offered an alternative to the AstraZeneca vaccine after a review into rare blood clots.

item.title: AstraZeneca vaccine: How do you weigh up the risks and benefits?
item.description: A guide to the risks and benefits of receiving the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine.

item.title: Should I take aspirin with my jab? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Under-30s will be not be offered the AstraZeneca vaccine, after concerns over rare blood clots.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The rules on how many people can meet outdoors are changing, as lockdown is eased.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: How to get a test for coronavirus
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for, and how do they work?

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: Anyone in England who travels abroad without good reason will soon face a £5000 fine.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 31 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: What are the UK plans for Covid passports?
item.description: The government is considering how people could prove they are unlikely to transmit Covid.

item.title: Covid: What is the rule of six and what are the social distancing rules?
item.description: Lockdown rules are being eased further in England and Wales so more people can meet up outside.

item.title: Covid: Can my boss force me to go to work?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about going to work?

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pools, gyms and hairdressers open?
item.description: Lockdown has been eased further - but what does it mean for hairdressers, pubs and gyms?

item.title: Covid: When can pubs and restaurants reopen?
item.description: Hospitality venues are set to gradually open up in the spring as lockdown eases across the UK.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for places of worship?
item.description: Places of worship are open across much of the UK, despite lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Why is the EU unhappy with AstraZeneca?
item.description: The EU has called on AstraZeneca to "catch up" on its deliveries to the EU.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and when can I hold a reception?
item.description: Wedding ceremonies are still restricted across the UK, but the rules are easing.

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: As the UK cautiously unlocks, experts will review the evidence on when and where masks are needed.

item.title: Covid: What's happened to crime during the pandemic?
item.description: From dog theft to drug crime, lockdown has led to some big changes in policing.

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The unemployment rate is rising as Covid hits different parts of the economy.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.

item.title: Covid: The countries that nailed it, and what we can learn from them
item.description: A year into the pandemic, we look at countries that have had some success in tackling the virus.

item.title: Race report: Was controversy part of the plan?
item.description: How the government handled the release of a contentious report on racial disparity in the UK.

item.title: 'We found a baby on the subway - now he's our son'
item.description: Danny Stewart saw something on the floor of an NY subway station - soon he would treasure it more than anything.

item.title: Letterbox contact: ‘Don’t my birth children have a right to know I’m dying?'
item.description: Diagnosed with a terminal illness, Hanna wanted to tell the twins taken from her at 16 - but had no way of reaching them.

item.title: The cost of speaking up against China
item.description: Uyghurs abroad describe a pattern of harassment and intimidation they say is designed to silence them.

item.title: The vaccine misinformation battle raging in France
item.description: Online conspiracy theories are exacerbating existing vaccine scepticism.
